A. Sample Testimony and Colloquy

Villamena - Direct

The advice and recommendations made to the

Court. Q In order for this patient to stand trial, which he did, there must have been a psychiatric examination and a report
rendered to the Court determining that he was competent to stand trial; is that
not correct?
MR. HOROWITZ: I object to the form of that
question, if your Honor please. THE COURT: Objection is sustained. Q Doctor, you referred to a program which
exists in a hospital, and you have indicated that this patient would benefit by
such a program; is that not correct?
A Yes, that is correct. Q Now, you heard the testimony of the two
psychiatric residents at Pilgrim State Hospital, did you not?
A Yes, I did. Q Did you hear them testify that there was
no further need for hospitalization at this time, Doctor?
A Yes, I heard them say that. Q I ask you again, Doctor, what program then
are you referring to which this patient would receive if he were retained in

Pilgrim State Hospital at this time?
A First of all, in view of the absence of
any recommendations relative to such a program, in view of the absence of any
program with the exception of an afternoon session with
B. Sample Title (1 page)

51

New York, New York

February 25, 1983

Indictment

No. 4485/82
-against-
RICHARD ROVERE, Burglary 2°
________Defendant. Wade Hearing
________
100 Centre Street

New York, New York 10013

January 10, 11, 12, 1984

Before: HONORABLE SHELDON P. HART, Justice

Appearances: MORGAN H. RILEY, ESQ. Special narcotics prosecutor for the

City of New York
BY: JOHN O'MALLEY, ESQ. Assistant District Attorney
STEPHEN SANDERS, ESQ. Attorney for Defendant Garrett
50 Court Street

Brooklyn, New York 11201
RAYMOND ARGONAUT, ESQ. Attorney for Defendant Rovere
470 Broadway

New York, New York 10013

Michael Spillane

Official Court Reporter
________
THE CLERK: Cases 1 and 2 on the calendar, the People versus Michael Garrett and Richard Rovere. Let the record indicate
the defendants, their counsel and the Assistant District Attorney are all
present. THE COURT: Call your first witness. MR. O'MALLEY: The People call Detective

Ruiz. DOMINGO RUIZ, Detective, a witness called on
behalf of the People, after having been first duly sworn and having stated his
shield number as 803 and his command as the 23 Precinct, New York City Police

Department, took the witness stand and testified as follows: DIRECT EXAMINATION
BY MR. O'MALLEY: Q Detective Ruiz, how long have you been a

New York City Police detective?
A About 14 years now. D. Sample Abbreviated Title
SUPREME COURT OF THE STATE OF NEW
YORK
COUNTY OF NEW YORK: CRIMINAL TERM: PART
47
________
THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK
Indictment

No. 7385/82
-against-
ROBERTS SANDERS, ________ Defendant. May 18, 1983
________
Before: HONORABLE KENNETH M. ARCHER, Justice, and a jury
(Appearances same as previously
noted.)
________
THE CLERK: Case on trial continuing; the
defendant is present with counsel and the Assistant District Attorney is
present. The jury is present. THE COURT: The witness will resume the
stand. JOHN P. MARQUAND, having been previously
duly sworn, resumed the witness stand and continued his testimony as
follows: DIRECT EXAMINATION (CONTINUED)
BY MR. MARTIN: Q Mr. Marquand, when we adjourned yesterday, you were describing the subway platform at 23rd Street to the members of the
jury. Will you now place a red "X" on the diagram to indicate your precise
position and that of the defendant when
